sentence.content: The republic of Slovenia plans to begin work on a constitution that will give it full sovereignty within a new Yugoslav confederation, the state Tanjug news agency reported Monday.

sentence.content: Slovenia, whose 2 million inhabitants account for a fraction of Yugoslavia&apost;s total population of 23 million, is the most politically liberal and prosperous of the country&apost;s six member republics.

sentence.content: Slovenia ``should be set up as a sovereign state, with all attributes of factual authority and with full international-legal rights,&apost;&apost; Tanjug said, quoting from a declaration of the Slovenian presidency, the top local ruling body.

sentence.content: The Slovenian move was endorsed by Slovenia&apost;s president, Milan Kucan, who told a Monday session of the presidency that the new constitution will be the ``constitution of the sovereign state of Slovenia, and not of one of the federal (republics),&apost;&apost; Tanjug said.

sentence.content: Slovenia has been frequently accused by politicians and the media in Yugoslavia&apost;s more conservative southern republics, and particularly in the country&apost;s largest republic of Serbia, of harboring separatist tendencies and of protecting its own interests at the expense of federal goals.

sentence.content: Slovenian authorities claim Serbia is trying to politically and economically dominate the Yugoslav federation by introducing greater federal control and by limiting the autonomy of the republics.

sentence.content: More than 70 percent of the residents of the northern republic believe their region might be better off if it were outside the Yugoslav federation, results of a public opinion poll said last March.

sentence.content: Both Slovenia and Croatia, the two Yugoslav republics that held free elections this year, have proclaimed a readiness to turn the Yugoslav federation of six republics and two provinces into a looser confederation of states cooperating voluntarily.
